tool.name: BrooksCorey
tool.displayname: 02 Calculate Brooks-Corey parameters and plot SMRC

param.name: Output_folder
param.dialogReference: Specify the path and folder name where output from this tool should be stored.

param.name: Input_shapefile
param.dialogReference: Specify the path and filename of the input soil shapefile. Soil shapefile can be polygon or point vector which includes required soil properties of the selected PTFs and a required field named "soilname" which contains the soils' name/identifier.

param.name: PTF_of_choice
param.expression: Cosby et al. (1984) - Sand and Clay | Cosby et al. (1984) - Sand, Silt and Clay | Rawls and Brakensiek (1985) | Campbell and Shiozawa (1992) | Saxton et al. (1986) | Saxton and Rawls (2006)
param.dialogReference:
Select the PTFs of interest from the dropdown list.Here are the current PTFs options and their required inputs:

(1) Temperate climate

- Cosby et al. (1984) (Equation with Sand, Silt, Clay): Sand, Silt, Clay

- Cosby et al. (1984) (Equation with Silt, Clay): Silt, Clay

- Rawls and Brakensiek (1985): Sand, Clay, θs

- Campbell and Shiozava (1992): Silt, Clay, BD, θs

- Saxton et al. (1986): Sand, Clay, θs

- Saxton and Rawls (2006): Sand, Clay, Organic Matter

param.name: Pressure_heads_BC
param.displayname: Specify pressures to calculate water content using Brooks-Corey model (space delimited)
param.dialogReference:
In the default, the outputshapefilewill contain soil moisture retention/hydraulic conductivity at -1kPa, -3kPa, -10kPa, -33kPa, -100kPa, -200kPa, -1000kPa and -1500kPa. These will get written to the output shapefile.

Using this option, the user can customise the output to get soil moisture/hydraulic conductivity at the pressure of interest, in addition to the default pressures. This information will get written to a csvfile within the output folder.

param.name: FieldCapacity
param.displayname: Value of pressure (kPa) at field capacity
param.dialogReference: Specify pressure for field capacity. Field capacity is commonly between -10kPa to -100kPa. The default value is -33kPa.

param.name: SIC
param.displayname: Value of pressure (kPa) at water stress-induced stomata closure
param.dialogReference: Specify pressure for water stress-induced stomata closure. The default value is -100kPa.

param.name: PWP
param.displayname: Value of pressure (kPa) at permanent wilting point
param.dialogReference: Specify pressure for permanent wilting point. The default value is -1500kPa.

param.name: Carbon_content
param.displayname: If the selected PTF requires OC or OM, select which type is present in your dataset:
param.dialogReference: Specifying soil carbon information in the input data.

param.name: Conversion_factor
param.displayname: If the selected PTF requires OC or OM, enter the appropriate conversion factor to change OM to OC (or vice-versa):
param.dialogReference: You do not need to use this function if your dataset has the same type of soil carbon as required by the PTFs. If the selected PTFs require organic matter (OM) but the input data only has organic carbon (OC) or inversely, this function can be used to convert OM to OC and inversely. NB_PTFs gives default conversion factors (the Van Bemmelen factors): 1.724 to convert OC to OM and 0.58 to convert OM to OC. However, the user can customise the factor by typing a converstion factor intothis field.

param.name: Pressure_units_plot
param.dialogReference: Selecting the pressure unit for plotting soil moisture result. NB_PTFs has thee pressure unit options: kPa, cm and m.

param.name: Plot_axis
param.displayname: Create water content and pressure plots with water content on the X-axis or Y-axis:
param.dialogReference: Choose which axis water content will be plotted on.

tool.summary: This tool provides 6 PTFs to estimate Brooks and Corey model parameters and the soil moisture-pressure relationship. To select the PTFs of interest, the user can use the guidelines given in the paper “Guidelines and a supporting toolbox for parameterising key soil hydraulic properties in hydrological studies and broader integrated modelling” (Dang et al., 2021).
